node.text:
The Hershey’s syrup surprised me! My hypothesis on that one was incorrect.

Carrageenan and gums belong to a group of food additives called hydrocolloids, which are a colloid (particle) mixed in water (hydro). They help to thicken and provide structure to many different foods.

Carrageenan helps to keep the cocoa suspended in chocolate milk. The xanthan gum in the Hershey’s syrup does the same as well as increasing viscosity to create a thicker, richer texture. The gellan gum that’s contained in the oat milk I showed in the last video helps to thicken, keep the vitamins and minerals suspended and helps to stabilize them as well.

Because of the increased viscosity, it takes longer for the beverages with hydrocolloids to diffuse into the cookie.

No Oreos were wasted in the making of this video. I even ate the super soggy one 😋

node.text:
Link in bio for an article I wrote on this subject with a boatload of references. These are just a few.

“A variety of human and animal intervention studies provided data on the effects of consumption of LES-sweetened liquids versus water. The results indicate that the exposure to sweetness itself (without energy) is at least neutral in terms of impact on EI and energy balance, and possibly even helpful. This challenges the suggestion that exposure to sweetness itself is detrimental, perhaps because exposure to sweetness could help ‘establish and maintain’ a more generalised preference for sweet items. Acquired preferences for sweetness levels are relatively food- specific, although this is expressed against the background of a general innate liking for sweetness. On the other hand, evidence from studies of ‘sensory-specific satiety’ show that acute exposure to sweetness decreases subsequent desire for the same or other sweet (relative to non-sweet) items. Consistent with this, participants in the CHOICE trial receiving LES beverages specifically reduced consumption of dessert items relative to those receiving water. One possible interpretation is that access to LES satisfies a pre-existing desire for sweetness, rather than promoting it.” (PMID: 26365102)

It’s always important to understand that these are just single ingredients. It’s not about being “good” vs “bad” or “unhealthy” vs “healthy.” They’re also not a silver bullet for weight loss, but perhaps can be a helpful tool or can just be enjoyed because you enjoy them! These compounds are some of the most extensively studied ingredients in our food supply. They can be a great alternative to sugar for those with diabetes as well.

#factsnotfear #dietsoda #dietcoke #aspartame #lowcaloriesweeteners #soda #food #nutrition #foodscience #science #scicomm #scicommunity

node.text:
Moisture, or water content, is a measure of the total amount of water contained in a food and is typically expressed as a percent of the total weight. Water Activity (aw), on the other hand, is a measure of the “free” or “unbound” water that is available to react and to be utilized by microorganisms. It’s measured on a scale from 0 to 1, where one indicates pure water and zero indicates the total absence of “free” water molecules. Moisture migrates from areas of high aw to areas of low aw until equilibrium is established.

I posted about water activity a while back when I debunked the “immortal fast food meal” myth and that it “lasts forever” due to preservatives, but it actually has more to do with water activity than preservatives. If the aw of the food is greater than that of the surrounding air, the moisture will migrate from the food to the air, thereby decreasing the aw of the food. If the equilibrium aw is lower than what is required for mold and bacterial growth and is reached before any microorganisms have had a chance to grow, then mold and bacteria simply won’t be present on the resulting dried out food. Drying, or dehydration, has been used to preserve foods such as fruit, meat, and bread for thousands of years.

Water activity is an important property to understand and control for when developing food products, especially those with multiple components like raisins and cereal flakes, for example. Either both components need to start with similar aw or they need to be acceptable when the water activity reaches equilibrium. It’s also an important factor to account for to ensure no mold or bacterial growth.

Check out my “food science” highlight for more information on water activity and my “experiments” highlight for a fun activity you can do at home to learn more about water activity!

#factsnotfear #fastfood #moisture #wateractivity #foodmicrobiology #foodsafety #foodscience #nutrition #food #microbiology #science #scicomm #scicommunity

node.text:
I covered this earlier in the year, but it seems to keep circulating and I continue to get questions about it. Please check out my PFAS highlight as well as the IGTV I did with PhD research chemist @chem.kardashian.

Also, just one more thing…it’s PFAS, not PFAs. This has been bothering me lately 😆

I’ve noticed a lot of the people spreading these sensationalized headlines and misinformation have been saying “PFAs.” At the VERY least, I wish they’d understand what the acronym stands for.

It’s not, like, referring to multiple units of PFA or phosphorus fluorine arsenic…

#factsnotfear #pfas #sparklingwater #topochico #lacroix #misinformation #chemistry #pfoa #science #foodscience #scicomm #scicommunity

node.text:
.
This is a common tactic that charlatans use, so watch out for these red flags 🚩

Please don't let anyone shame you for formula feeding...especially not someone who thinks vitamins and minerals are bad for them because he can't pronounce their scientific names.

I’d also like to add that an increase in “childhood developmental issues” isn’t necessarily a bad thing either. Many have increased due to better diagnosis, not because they didn’t exist before.

You can’t just decide that every food or ingredient you don’t understand is the cause of every issue or disease you don’t understand or that we may not know all of the causes for yet. Even if there is a correlation, we know that correlation does not equal causation either.

Infant formula is one of the most researched, regulated and safest food products on the market. Don’t let charlatans like him convince you otherwise. 

#factsnotfear #infantformula #charlatan #babyformula #fedisbest #formula #instababy #instamom #formulashaming #misinformation #fearmongering #nutrition #foodscience #science #scicomm #scicommunity

node.text:
.
There are many different types of wheat flour too!

ALL-PURPOSE FLOUR
Refined and made from a combination of hard and soft wheat. Can be used universally for a wide range of baked products – yeast breads, cakes, cookies and pastries. Has added iron, and four B-vitamins (thiamin, niacin, riboflavin and folic acid) added in amounts equal to or exceeding what is present in whole wheat flour. Virtually all white flour sold in the United States is enriched (over 95%).

BREAD FLOUR 
Refined and milled primarily for commercial baking use, but can be found at most grocery stores. Similar to all-purpose flour, but has a higher gluten content, which is optimal in making yeast breads. 

SELF-RISING FLOUR
A type of all-purpose flour that has salt and a leavening agent added. Commonly used in biscuits and quick breads or even cookies, but is not recommended for yeast breads. 

CAKE FLOUR
Refined, fine-textured, almost silky flour milled from soft wheat and has a low protein content. Used to make all types of baked goods like cakes, cookies, crackers, quick breads and some types of pastry.

PASTRY FLOUR 
Properties fall between allpurpose flour and cake flour. It is usually made from soft wheat for pastry making, but can be used for cookies, cakes, crackers and similarly baked products. Slightly higher protein content than cake flour and less starch. 

SEMOLINA 
Coarsely ground endosperm of durum wheat—the hardest variety of the six classes of wheat and has the highest protein content of all wheat. Ideal for making high quality pasta and is also used to make couscous.

DURUM FLOUR 
A by-product in the production of semolina. It is usually enriched with four B vitamins and iron and used to make noodles.

WHOLE WHEAT FLOUR 
Unrefined—milled from the entire kernel of wheat.

GRAHAM FLOUR 
Coarsely ground whole wheat flour. Named after Dr. Sylvester Graham, the creator of the graham cracker, who advocated the use of whole wheat flour in the early 1800s.

STONE GROUND 
Type of whole wheat flour that has been milled by crushing the kernel between two rotating stones. There is no nutritional difference.

HIGH-GLUTEN FLOUR 
High protein content usually milled from hard spring wheat

node.text:
Absolutely fact check things you see on social media, but also make sure you’re fact checking with reputable sources. It can be tricky sometimes, but citing your Google search results on a topic is not a valid citation. I had so many people over on TikTok citing random blogs to let me know that salt is in fact bleached (it’s not) because it came up as the first few results of their Google search. One particular blog also claims that the refining process heats up salt so that it changes the chemical structure. That should be a huge red flag that the source is either just making stuff up or repeating what they’ve seen from another unreliable source. Refined NaCl is obviously still NaCl, and is in fact more pure when the impurities have been removed.

The additional minerals in salts that may be different colors are often touted as better for your health, but they’re not. Any additional minerals are at such low levels that you’d have to eat a large amount of the salt to get any meaningful dose. In addition, you’re missing out on potentially necessary added iodine if not purchasing the kind with iodine.

Demonizing certain types of NaCl, especially the kind with added iodine while touting non existent benefits of salt with some impurities (hello Himalayan pink salt) is the epitome of wellness culture: looks good on the gram, your favorite celeb probably has a post about how it makes their skin glow, it’s more expensive than the stuff these influencers are telling you not to buy, oh and they probably have a discount code for it too ✅

Bottom line: NaCl is NaCl. It is not bleached. Some has added iodine, which can be beneficial if you’re not getting enough elsewhere in your diet. 

So please, take these NaCl claims with a grain of salt. 

#factsnotfear #salt #saltbleaching #food #foodmyths #foodfacts #misinformation #foodscience #iodizedsalt #nutrition #science #scicomm #scicommunity

node.text:
A common fearmongering tactic is to gross people out or mislead by claiming an ingredient is the same as what it’s derived from. So, yes, cellulose can be derived from wood pulp and refined into cellulose powder used in foods, but that doesn’t mean it IS wood pulp. In shredded and grated cheese it can help prevent the cheese from sticking together and gives grated cheese better flowability.

The account that I stitched continually perpetuates misinformation that is not only incredibly classist (claiming grass fed and organic is more nutritious and superior when that’s not the case) but ableist as well. I’ve covered this in another video on shredded cheese, but some people physically can’t shred their own or it’s much easier for them to buy shredded. It’s ableist to unnecessarily scare consumers over ingredients added to more accessible foods and to imply or flat out make blanket statements that everyone should shred their own otherwise they’re doing something bad for their health.

Cinnamon anyone? 🤷🏼‍♀️

#factsnotfear #cheese #dairy #cellulose #nutrition #food #misinformation #foodscience #science #scicomm #scicommunity

node.title: Wood Pulp In Cheese? & Cheese Lawsuits

node.text:
.
⭐️Please Watch All 3 Videos⭐️

Fun Facts:

• In the EU 38 colours are authorised as colour additives for use in foods together with canthaxanthin that is no longer authorised in food but is still included for its use in drugs. In the US, there are 36 approved food colour additives.

• 5 colour additives approved in the US are not permitted in the EU, including 3 of synthetic origin.

• 15 colour additives authorised in the EU are not allowed in the US, including 9 colours of synthetic origin and lutein, vegetable carbon, aluminium, silver and gold, chlorophylls and chlorophyllins.

• The impact of banning several synthetic colours in the US, potentially requiring EU exporters to reformulate their products, is alleviated by progressive replacing of colours of synthetic origin by natural alternatives in the EU market.

I have so many videos and posts now covering this, so please take a look at my previous “banned in Europe” IGTV videos as well. Whether a food or ingredient is banned in another country tells you precisely nothing about its safety or the safety of a product it’s contained in.

The default seems to be that if a product in a specific country doesn’t contain an ingredient that’s in an analogous product in another country then the one without it is safer. That just makes entirely no sense from a scientific perspective. These ingredients are often banned or not approved due to various reasons including political or just consumer preference. It doesn’t automatically mean it’s safer if banned or not added.

There have been some updates since this article, such as EU banning titanium dioxide and US allowing calcium carbonate, so I updated the numbers in the post accordingly. If you know of any other updates since 2017, please let me know 😊

https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/19440049.2016.1274431

Approved additives and E numbers in the UK:

https://www.food.gov.uk/business-guidance/approved-additives-and-e-numbers

#factsnotfear #fooddyes #foodcolors #foodingredients #bannedineurope #misinformation #factcheck #food #foodscience #science #scicomm #scicommunity

🚨FACT CHECKING HACK🚨

Is Subway tuna actually tuna?

I’ve been tagged in this one a bunch, so here you go!

I also want to add that there is no reason to believe it’s not tuna. These allegations were brought against Subway without evidence that it isn’t tuna.

Subway also noted that the plaintiffs in the lawsuit have backed off the claim somewhat: "Even the plaintiffs have softened their original claims. In a new filing from June, their complaints centered not on whether Subway's tuna was tuna at all, but whether it was '100% sustainably caught skipjack and yellowfin tuna,' the statement read. 

#subway #subwaytuna #subwaysandwich #inthenews #plantbased #instafood #foodscience #science #scicomm #scicommunity

node.text:
I talk more about this on a recent episode of @jordanlipsfitness podcast, and explain more about some of these fear based marketing labels.

#factsnotfear #questionyourbias #science #organicfood #nongmo #gmo #foodscience #scicommunity #scicomm #food #confirmationbias #foodmarketing

The same savory, rich, “umami” flavor that MSG contributes can be found in foods such as tomatoes, soy sauce, parmesan cheese, yeast extract and mushrooms, which contain naturally occurring glutamate, the deprotonated form of glutamic acid. Glutamate is a naturally occurring amino acid that our bodies produce to survive. It serves as a neurotransmitter in the brain in addition to its general role in protein and energy metabolism. 

The glutamate in MSG is chemically indistinguishable from glutamate in our bodies and in food proteins, and our bodies metabolize both sources in the same way. Additionally, an average adult consumes approximately 13 grams of glutamate each day from the protein in food, while intake of added MSG is estimated at around 0.55 grams per day. Daily, we ingest 20 to 40 times more naturally occurring glutamate than we do from MSG.

MSG is one of the most intensely studied food ingredients in the food supply and has been found to be so safe that The Joint Expert Committee on Food Additives of the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization and World Health Organization placed it in the safest category for food additives.

It can also help to reduce sodium intake. MSG contains about 12 percent sodium — two-thirds less than that contained in table salt. Data show that up to a 50 percent reduction in sodium is possible in specific product categories (like packaged foods and snacks) when MSG is substituted for some salt. A 2020 study determined that replacing some table salt with MSG in recipes can reduce the sodium content by up to 61% without compromising flavor (https://doi.org/10.1111/1750-3841.15354).

For more information, please visit: www.knowmsg.com (link in bio) #KnowMSG #AjiPartner

node.text:
The Hershey’s syrup surprised me! My hypothesis on that one was incorrect.

Carrageenan and gums belong to a group of food additives called hydrocolloids, which are a colloid (particle) mixed in water (hydro). They help to thicken and provide structure to many different foods.

Carrageenan helps to keep the cocoa suspended in chocolate milk. The xanthan gum in the Hershey’s syrup does the same as well as increasing viscosity to create a thicker, richer texture. The gellan gum that’s contained in the oat milk I showed in the last video helps to thicken, keep the vitamins and minerals suspended and helps to stabilize them as well.

Because of the increased viscosity, it takes longer for the beverages with hydrocolloids to diffuse into the cookie.

#oreo @oreo #hersheys #hersheyssyrup @hersheys #notanad #scienceexperiment #milk #chocolatemilk #carrageenan #experiment #science #foodexperiment #foodscience #food #oreosandmilk #scicomm #scicommunity

node.text:
Link in bio for an article I wrote on this subject with a boatload of references. These are just a few.

“A variety of human and animal intervention studies provided data on the effects of consumption of LES-sweetened liquids versus water. The results indicate that the exposure to sweetness itself (without energy) is at least neutral in terms of impact on EI and energy balance, and possibly even helpful. This challenges the suggestion that exposure to sweetness itself is detrimental, perhaps because exposure to sweetness could help ‘establish and maintain’ a more generalised preference for sweet items. Acquired preferences for sweetness levels are relatively food- specific, although this is expressed against the background of a general innate liking for sweetness. On the other hand, evidence from studies of ‘sensory-specific satiety’ show that acute exposure to sweetness decreases subsequent desire for the same or other sweet (relative to non-sweet) items. Consistent with this, participants in the CHOICE trial receiving LES beverages specifically reduced consumption of dessert items relative to those receiving water. One possible interpretation is that access to LES satisfies a pre-existing desire for sweetness, rather than promoting it.” (PMID: 26365102)

It’s always important to understand that these are just single ingredients. It’s not about being “good” vs “bad” or “unhealthy” vs “healthy.” They’re also not a silver bullet for weight loss, but perhaps can be a helpful tool or can just be enjoyed because you enjoy them! These compounds are some of the most extensively studied ingredients in our food supply. They can be a great alternative to sugar for those with diabetes as well.

#factsnotfear #dietsoda #dietcoke #aspartame #lowcaloriesweeteners #soda #food #nutrition #foodscience #science #scicomm #scicommunity

node.text:
Moisture, or water content, is a measure of the total amount of water contained in a food and is typically expressed as a percent of the total weight. Water Activity (aw), on the other hand, is a measure of the “free” or “unbound” water that is available to react and to be utilized by microorganisms. It’s measured on a scale from 0 to 1, where one indicates pure water and zero indicates the total absence of “free” water molecules. Moisture migrates from areas of high aw to areas of low aw until equilibrium is established.

I posted about water activity a while back when I debunked the “immortal fast food meal” myth and that it “lasts forever” due to preservatives, but it actually has more to do with water activity than preservatives. If the aw of the food is greater than that of the surrounding air, the moisture will migrate from the food to the air, thereby decreasing the aw of the food. If the equilibrium aw is lower than what is required for mold and bacterial growth and is reached before any microorganisms have had a chance to grow, then mold and bacteria simply won’t be present on the resulting dried out food. Drying, or dehydration, has been used to preserve foods such as fruit, meat, and bread for thousands of years.

Water activity is an important property to understand and control for when developing food products, especially those with multiple components like raisins and cereal flakes, for example. Either both components need to start with similar aw or they need to be acceptable when the water activity reaches equilibrium. It’s also an important factor to account for to ensure no mold or bacterial growth.

Check out my “food science” highlight for more information on water activity and my “experiments” highlight for a fun activity you can do at home to learn more about water activity!

#factsnotfear #fastfood #moisture #wateractivity #foodmicrobiology #foodsafety #foodscience #nutrition #food #microbiology #science #scicomm #scicommunity

node.text:
Check out my merch shop for this design and much more! Link in bio.

There are so many misconceptions surrounding these marketing labels. 

➡️Natural does not equal safer or healthier. Whether a chemical is natural or synthetic tells you precisely nothing about its toxicity. Some of the most toxic chemicals known are natural...hello botulinum toxin!

➡️ It is a global scientific consensus that transgenic crops are just as safe and at least as nutritious as their non transgenic counterparts.

➡️Probably the biggest misconception about organic is that organic doesn’t use pesticides, but that is false. Organic farmers are allowed to use approved organic pesticides as well as some approved synthetic pesticides. 

➡️Organic and “non-GMO” foods are no safer or more nutritious than their conventional counterparts. There is very little evidence showing significant differences in nutritional value of organic and conventional foods. Any differences that have been found are too small to have any effects on human health.

Check out my “GMO,” “pesticides” and “organic” highlights for references and more info.
.
.
#factsnotfear #natural #organic #nongmo #gmo #agriculture #farming #pesticides #naturaldoesnotmeansafe #organicusespesticides #organicisnothealthier #food #foodscience #scicomm #scicommunication #science #scicommunity

node.text:
I covered this earlier in the year, but it seems to keep circulating and I continue to get questions about it. Please check out my PFAS highlight as well as the IGTV I did with PhD research chemist @chem.kardashian.

Also, just one more thing…it’s PFAS, not PFAs. This has been bothering me lately 😆

I’ve noticed a lot of the people spreading these sensationalized headlines and misinformation have been saying “PFAs.” At the VERY least, I wish they’d understand what the acronym stands for.

It’s not, like, referring to multiple units of PFA or phosphorus fluorine arsenic…

#factsnotfear #pfas #sparklingwater #topochico #lacroix #misinformation #chemistry #pfoa #science #foodscience #scicomm #scicommunity

node.text:
.
This is a common tactic that charlatans use, so watch out for these red flags 🚩

Please don't let anyone shame you for formula feeding...especially not someone who thinks vitamins and minerals are bad for them because he can't pronounce their scientific names.

I’d also like to add that an increase in “childhood developmental issues” isn’t necessarily a bad thing either. Many have increased due to better diagnosis, not because they didn’t exist before.

You can’t just decide that every food or ingredient you don’t understand is the cause of every issue or disease you don’t understand or that we may not know all of the causes for yet. Even if there is a correlation, we know that correlation does not equal causation either.

Infant formula is one of the most researched, regulated and safest food products on the market. Don’t let charlatans like him convince you otherwise. 

#factsnotfear #infantformula #charlatan #babyformula #fedisbest #formula #instababy #instamom #formulashaming #misinformation #fearmongering #nutrition #foodscience #science #scicomm #scicommunity

node.text:
.
There are many different types of wheat flour too!

ALL-PURPOSE FLOUR
Refined and made from a combination of hard and soft wheat. Can be used universally for a wide range of baked products – yeast breads, cakes, cookies and pastries. Has added iron, and four B-vitamins (thiamin, niacin, riboflavin and folic acid) added in amounts equal to or exceeding what is present in whole wheat flour. Virtually all white flour sold in the United States is enriched (over 95%).

BREAD FLOUR 
Refined and milled primarily for commercial baking use, but can be found at most grocery stores. Similar to all-purpose flour, but has a higher gluten content, which is optimal in making yeast breads. 

SELF-RISING FLOUR
A type of all-purpose flour that has salt and a leavening agent added. Commonly used in biscuits and quick breads or even cookies, but is not recommended for yeast breads. 

CAKE FLOUR
Refined, fine-textured, almost silky flour milled from soft wheat and has a low protein content. Used to make all types of baked goods like cakes, cookies, crackers, quick breads and some types of pastry.

PASTRY FLOUR 
Properties fall between allpurpose flour and cake flour. It is usually made from soft wheat for pastry making, but can be used for cookies, cakes, crackers and similarly baked products. Slightly higher protein content than cake flour and less starch. 

SEMOLINA 
Coarsely ground endosperm of durum wheat—the hardest variety of the six classes of wheat and has the highest protein content of all wheat. Ideal for making high quality pasta and is also used to make couscous.

DURUM FLOUR 
A by-product in the production of semolina. It is usually enriched with four B vitamins and iron and used to make noodles.

WHOLE WHEAT FLOUR 
Unrefined—milled from the entire kernel of wheat.

GRAHAM FLOUR 
Coarsely ground whole wheat flour. Named after Dr. Sylvester Graham, the creator of the graham cracker, who advocated the use of whole wheat flour in the early 1800s.

STONE GROUND 
Type of whole wheat flour that has been milled by crushing the kernel between two rotating stones. There is no nutritional difference.

HIGH-GLUTEN FLOUR 
High protein content usually milled from hard spring wheat

node.text:
Absolutely fact check things you see on social media, but also make sure you’re fact checking with reputable sources. It can be tricky sometimes, but citing your Google search results on a topic is not a valid citation. I had so many people over on TikTok citing random blogs to let me know that salt is in fact bleached (it’s not) because it came up as the first few results of their Google search. One particular blog also claims that the refining process heats up salt so that it changes the chemical structure. That should be a huge red flag that the source is either just making stuff up or repeating what they’ve seen from another unreliable source. Refined NaCl is obviously still NaCl, and is in fact more pure when the impurities have been removed.

The additional minerals in salts that may be different colors are often touted as better for your health, but they’re not. Any additional minerals are at such low levels that you’d have to eat a large amount of the salt to get any meaningful dose. In addition, you’re missing out on potentially necessary added iodine if not purchasing the kind with iodine.

Demonizing certain types of NaCl, especially the kind with added iodine while touting non existent benefits of salt with some impurities (hello Himalayan pink salt) is the epitome of wellness culture: looks good on the gram, your favorite celeb probably has a post about how it makes their skin glow, it’s more expensive than the stuff these influencers are telling you not to buy, oh and they probably have a discount code for it too ✅

Bottom line: NaCl is NaCl. It is not bleached. Some has added iodine, which can be beneficial if you’re not getting enough elsewhere in your diet. 

So please, take these NaCl claims with a grain of salt. 

#factsnotfear #salt #saltbleaching #food #foodmyths #foodfacts #misinformation #foodscience #iodizedsalt #nutrition #science #scicomm #scicommunity

node.text:
.
Who bleached the salt flats?? 😆

Yes, I’m obsessed with this song. Thanks again @yourpal_austin 🙌🏼

Salt can be refined to remove impurities and make it whiter, but it is not bleached. NaCl is a halide. When an alkali metal (sodium in this case) is combined with a halogen (chlorine in this case) it creates a white solid at room temperature.

Pure NaCl is white, so stating “if salt is perfectly white like this it means it was bleached” just really shows a misunderstanding of basic chemistry.

Salts such as Himalayan pink salt are different colors due to impurities, such as different minerals. If that salt was refined to remove those impurities, you’d be left with pure NaCl—a white solid.

I’ll go into more detail in a future video, but for now just enjoy this gem. It obviously took me quite a while to shoot and edit and was paid for by Big Salt…also obviously 😅

#factsnotfear #salt #saltflats #misinformation #food #foodscience #chemistry #science #sciencefun #funnyvideos #funnymemes #scienceisfun #scicomm #scicommunity

node.text:
A common fearmongering tactic is to gross people out or mislead by claiming an ingredient is the same as what it’s derived from. So, yes, cellulose can be derived from wood pulp and refined into cellulose powder used in foods, but that doesn’t mean it IS wood pulp. In shredded and grated cheese it can help prevent the cheese from sticking together and gives grated cheese better flowability.

The account that I stitched continually perpetuates misinformation that is not only incredibly classist (claiming grass fed and organic is more nutritious and superior when that’s not the case) but ableist as well. I’ve covered this in another video on shredded cheese, but some people physically can’t shred their own or it’s much easier for them to buy shredded. It’s ableist to unnecessarily scare consumers over ingredients added to more accessible foods and to imply or flat out make blanket statements that everyone should shred their own otherwise they’re doing something bad for their health.

Cinnamon anyone? 🤷🏼‍♀️

#factsnotfear #cheese #dairy #cellulose #nutrition #food #misinformation #foodscience #science #scicomm #scicommunity
